column4: hello, i've just bought an external hard disk drive but i am encountering problems with permissions when i am mounting it. Only root can write. How can i tell the system to automatically mount it with rw permission for all users?
What filesystem is the drive?
ext3
Then just change the ownership using chown
i want to write automatically, not by telling it explicitly, isn't there a way?
What do you mean you want to write automatically? If only root can write that means you have to change the file's protection, chmod and/or chown should do the trick.
i mean that i would like to have the disk mounted automatically with rw permissions for me, isn't there a way to accomplish that?
I'm not sure; It's all in the permissions, you'd have to change them to make it rw

i found another way...I put a line in fstab for that device with options (users,rw,noauto). I mount with "mount /mnt./ext-disk", then changed the ownership of the mount point to me, i unmounted and now every time that i mount it with that command i am able to write
no that is not true
Oh? I thought that's what you said you did.
simply now i can write to the hard disk, meaning that i can create NEW files and remove them or edit, delete old files with permissions that allow me to do so
Yes, I know, but how did you get them to be rw without changing permissions?
notice what am i saying, i have rw perms only to the mount point. That only means i can CREATE NEW files and delete them, but not that i can delete older files which haven't got w permissions
Oh oh oh, so you're still having your problem then?
Well, just as I thought, you'll *probably* have to change the permissions. If there is some other way to do it it's above me.
No, i wanted to be able to create new files
Oh, okay. Sorry about my stupidity, it's early in the morning here.
but, yes, it did need to change only once the permissions of the mount point
ideally i would like to plug my device and not have to give the command "mount /mnt/..", instead have the system automounting it with the appropriate perms
Ah, the only program I can think of that automounts is gnome-volume-manager; And I'm not even sure if it works for external HDDs
